tit.e: Kokumen no sho (a shoen allowed exemption from so or other tribute in bempo or binho system)
Kokumen no sho (a shoen allowed exemption from so or other tribute in THE bempo or binho system)
tit.cmt: タイトルですので、補足を削除しました。

sen.j: 国免荘（こくめんのしょう）は、平安時代後期の荘園のうち、国司によって諸役の免除を受けたもの。
sen.e: Kokumen no sho (also referred to as Kokumensho) was a kind of shoen (manor in medieval Japan) in the late Heian period which was exempt from miscellaneous taxes by kokushi (provincial governor.)

sen.j: 平安時代後期に入ると、地方統治における国司の権限は強力となり、荒田などの諸役免除などを決定する権限を保持するようになる。
sen.e: In the late Heian period, kokushi became influential in the provincial government and assumed the authority to decide shoekimenjo (exemption of miscellaneous taxes) on Arata (also referred to as Areta; rice field of low grade) and the like.

sen.j: これを不輸の権 (日本)・不入の権 (日本)を獲得した荘園に対しても適用を拡大しようとしたのが国免荘である。
sen.e: Kokushi managed to extend his influence even to shoen that had already been granted Fuyu no ken (the right of tax exemption, Japan) and Funyu no ken (the right to keep the tax agents from entering the property, Japan), which had resulted in Kokumen no sho.

sen.e: Therefore, the lords of shoen wanted their lands to be granted much stronger Kanshofu sho (a shoen enjoying immunity from taxation by virtue of having official documents from both the Council of State and the Ministry of Popular Affairs) or Chokumen sho (imperially exempted manor.)
